M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 authorizes the Court to modify judgments regarding custody and visitation upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and that the modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.

M.G.L. c. 209C.proposition: To the extent this matter may also fall under or implicate the provisions of M.G.L. c. 209C (for custody and support of children born outside of marriage, where applicable), M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20 likewise permits modification of existing orders upon a showing of a substantial change in circumstances and the best interests of the child.

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Any modification of custody or parenting time must be based on the best interests of the child.

M.G.L. c. 215, \u00a7\u00a7 3 and 6.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 215, §§ 3 and 6, and M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, because the existing custody order was entered in this Court and the minor child resides within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: To the extent this matter may also fall under or implicate the provisions of M.G.L. c. 209C (for custody and support of children born outside of marriage, where applicable), M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20 likewise permits modification of existing orders upon a showing of a substantial change in circumstances and the best interests of the child.

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.raw_text: Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985) (best interests of the child are paramount in custody decisions)
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: Any modification of custody or parenting time must be based on the best interests of the child.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The case does emphasize that the best interests of the child are paramount in custody and removal decisions, but it does not speak to “any modification of custody or parenting time.” Yannas concerns an initial custody award in a divorce judgment and the custodial parent’s request to remove the children from the Commonwealth, not subsequent modifications of existing orders. While its best-interests language is broad, using this case as authority for the specific proposition about any modification of custody or parenting time is an overextension of its holding.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.proposition: Massachusetts courts require a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances, and (2) that modification is in the child’s best interests.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion addresses the standard for removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30 in the context of joint physical custody, not the general standard for modification of custody orders. It repeatedly frames the inquiry as whether there is “cause shown,” defined as whether removal is in the children’s best interests, and does not require or discuss a threshold showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances. The only reference to “substantial change in circumstances” is in a quoted ALI principle, not as a Massachusetts requirement, so the case does not support the two-part proposition stated.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that “[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of or has resided five years within this [C]ommonwealth and over whose custody and maintenance a probate court has jurisdiction shall not ... be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth ... if under [the] age [of consent], without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.” “The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.” Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985)… “Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 370\u.proposition: Massachusetts courts require a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances, and (2) that modification is in the child’s best interests.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 370\u.support_reasoning: The case clearly states that to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must show a material change in circumstances, but it does not articulate a separate, explicit requirement that the court also find that modification is in the child’s best interests. While it quotes G.L. c. 208, § 28’s language about child support being modifiable as the circumstances and benefit of the children may require, the opinion frames the operative standard as a material change in circumstances and an exercise of the judge’s discretion, not as a two-prong “material change plus best interests” test. Thus it partially but not fully supports the claimed proposition.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 370\u.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. … In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. … An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28…”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.proposition: Where there is a significant change in a child’s developmental stage, schooling, and a parent’s housing stability, modification of a parenting schedule to meet the child’s current needs is appropriate.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.support_reasoning: The case is not a modification proceeding and does not turn on a significant change in the child’s developmental stage, schooling, or the parents’ housing stability. It is a first-instance custody determination under the “best interests” standard, focused on primary caretaker status, stability, and the parties’ work schedules, not on a later modification to meet new developmental or schooling needs. Thus, it does not establish that a change in developmental stage, schooling, and housing stability makes modification of a parenting schedule appropriate.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.relevant_excerpt: "The required considerations of the second paragraph of G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), neither replace the 'best interests of the child' standard nor limit the factors that a judge may consider in determining what custodial arrangements are in the best interests of the child... If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child..."

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 266–267 (2001) (recognizing importance of stability and environment)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: The Father’s improved housing—now a private apartment with a dedicated bedroom for Ethan—removes the primary reason the Court previously restricted overnights and permits a schedule that better fosters a meaningful relationship with both parents, consistent with Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 266–267 (2001) (recognizing importance of stability and environment) and M.G.L. c. 208, § 31.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss overnights or housing conditions per se, but it repeatedly emphasizes that custody and relocation decisions must focus on the child’s welfare, stability, and living environment, including that both parents have “safe and secure homes” and that the child is “happy in each party’s home.” The court also notes that the child has “his own bedroom in each party’s house,” showing that the physical environment and stability of each home are relevant factors in determining arrangements that best serve the child’s interests. Thus, the case can fairly be cited for the general principle that stability and home environment are important to custody/parenting-time decisions, though the link to removing prior overnight restrictions is inferential rather than explicit.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “The probate judge took note of the fact that both parents love the child, and that ‘both parents have safe and secure homes. … The child is happy in each party’s home.’ … The only direct reference touching on Rosenthal’s relationship with Caleb is the finding that he gives Caleb cello lessons. The findings that ‘[b]oth parents have safe and secure homes. … The minor child is comfortable and has his own bedroom in each party’s house,’ indirectly support the conclusion that the mother’s remarriage has had no detrimental impact on Caleb.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404–405 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: Massachusetts law favors arrangements that encourage frequent and continuing contact with both parents, where consistent with the child’s best interests.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly endorses the principle that the law values frequent and continuing contact between children and both parents, quoting Felton v. Felton for that point. While the court ultimately upholds reduced visitation in light of the specific facts and best-interest analysis, its reasoning affirmatively recognizes, as a general rule, that Massachusetts law favors arrangements maintaining such contact, consistent with the child’s best interests.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “The husband does argue, however, that it is most often preferred that both parents participate in the child rearing process and in the major decisions that attach thereto. We agree with the precept that ‘the law sees a value in “frequent and continuing contact” of the child[ren] with both . . . parents.’ Felton v. Felton, supra at 234, quoting from In re Marriage of Murga, 103 Cal. App. 3d 498, 503 (1980)….”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 900 (1981) (modification warranted when existing order no longer serves its intended purpose)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The parties’ mutual recognition that modification is needed supports a finding that the existing order is no longer workable and that a new schedule will better serve Ethan’s best interests, consistent with Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 900 (1981) (modification warranted when existing order no longer serves its intended purpose).
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns standards for an initial custody award and emphasizes that custody decisions must be based on the child’s welfare and a weighing of all relevant best‑interest factors. It does not address modification of an existing order, mutual recognition by the parties that a modification is needed, or the concept of an order no longer serving its intended purpose. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition for which it is cited.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.proposition: In determining the best interests of the child, the Court may consider, among other factors: the child’s age and developmental stage, the child’s relationship with each parent, the child’s current living and school situation, and each parent’s ability to provide stability and meet the child’s needs.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on the need for explicit findings about domestic violence and its effects on the child in custody determinations, not on a general list of best-interest factors such as age, developmental stage, school situation, or each parent’s ability to provide stability. While the court mentions the child’s doing well in school, his preference, and his relationship with the father, it does so descriptively, not as a doctrinal statement of the factors courts may or must consider. The holding is about requiring findings on domestic violence, so the case does not clearly establish the multi-factor best-interests test stated in the proposition.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ … The Probate Court failed to consider the special risks to the child in awarding custody to a father who had committed acts of violence against the mother. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.proposition: In determining the best interests of the child, the Court may consider, among other factors: the child’s age and developmental stage, the child’s relationship with each parent, the child’s current living and school situation, and each parent’s ability to provide stability and meet the child’s needs.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the best-interests analysis as requiring consideration of a wide range of factors and then applies that standard to Hugo’s circumstances. In doing so, the court discusses Hugo’s young age and developmental delays, his attachments and relationships (with his foster mother, sister, and aunt), the stability and characteristics of his current home environment, and each proposed caretaker’s ability to provide consistency and meet his special needs. This aligns with the proposition that these types of factors are proper considerations in determining a child’s best interests.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.relevant_excerpt: “When the choice is between two caretakers, each of whom seeks to be the substitute for the child’s biological parents, a judge may consider a wide range of permissible evidence in determining which placement will serve the child’s best interests… Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development.”

Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 63 Mass. App.raw_text: Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 63 Mass. App. Ct. 908, 909–910 (2005) (rescript opinion) (upholding adjustments in parenting time to accommodate school and routine)
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 63 Mass. App.proposition: For school‑aged children, courts recognize that the structure of the school week and the need for routine are highly relevant in assessing parenting schedules.
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 63 Mass. App.case_name: Massachusetts Correction Officers Federated Union v. Commissioner of Correction
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 63 Mass. App.support_reasoning: The opinion text provided concerns enforcement and confirmation of an arbitration award in a labor dispute between a union and a state agency. It does not involve family law, custody, parenting schedules, or any discussion of school‑aged children, school‑week structure, or routine. The citation to Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser and the described proposition about parenting time and school routines are unrelated to the actual subject matter of this opinion, so this case cannot support that proposition.
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 63 Mass. App.relevant_excerpt: "The union does not allege a new violation of the collective bargaining agreement requiring resolution by the grievance procedure and arbitration. At issue here is nothing more than the enforcement of the underlying arbitration award, warranting its confirmation in a judgment of the court."

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409\u2.proposition: Any modification ordered by the Court must be grounded in Ethan’s welfare and best interests, not the preferences of the parents, but here the parents’ agreement that the existing plan is no longer appropriate reinforces that modification is in Ethan’s best interests.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in custody matters the governing and controlling principle is the welfare of the child, not the parents’ wishes, while noting that parental feelings and wishes may still be considered. This aligns with the first half of the proposition: any modification (or custody order) must be grounded in the child’s welfare rather than parental preferences. Although the case does not specifically address parents’ mutual agreement as reinforcing best interests, it clearly provides authority that the child’s welfare is paramount and parents’ wishes are secondary but relevant, which is the core legal principle being cited.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.… In providing for the custody of a minor child, while the feelings and the wishes of the parents should not be disregarded, the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration.”
